explanations: The translator added the conjunction "and yet" to explicitly link the preceding expression of surprise ("this is very surprizing") with the observation of order. This logical connection (concession/contrast) is only implied by juxtaposition in the source text, and the addition aids flow in English.

The French "a eu en veüe" (had in view/considered) is rendered as "took time to consider." The phrase "took time to" is an elaboration by the translator, suggesting a more deliberate and careful process by Nature than the original French strictly implies, thus adding a layer of interpretative nuance.

The translator added "pray," to the translation of "Mais attendez" (But wait). While "attendez" is a direct address, "pray" is a common English interjection of the period often used for politeness or to add emphasis when posing a question or making a statement, subtly altering the tone.

The translator transformed the Marquise's declarative realization "il me semble que Mars... n'a point de Lune" (it seems to me that Mars... has no Moon) into a direct question "why has not Mars a Moon too?". The interrogative word "why" and the comparative/emphatic "too" are additions that make the dialogue more explicitly inquisitive and probing.

The French "des Phosphores naturels" (natural Phosphoruses, or some natural Phosphoruses) is translated as "so many natural Phosphorus's." The addition of "so many" serves to emphasize the quantity or the idea that the rocks function as a multitude of individual phosphors, an emphasis not explicitly present in the French indefinite article "des."

The French "Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable" (You would not deny it would be a rather agreeable spectacle / You couldn't help but find it an agreeable spectacle) is a somewhat indirect rhetorical statement about the listener's presumed reaction. The translator changed this into a direct question and address, "What think you, Madam,", making the philosopher's interaction with the Marquise more explicit, personal, and engaging for the reader.

The French phrase "& faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques" (and make magnificent illuminations without any artifice/naturally) describes naturally produced, splendid light displays. The translator added the simile "like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night?" to provide a concrete and culturally familiar comparison for the English audience of the time, making the description more vivid and relatable.

The source states that the birds "vont répandre un nouveau jour" (go to spread a new day). The translator added the phrase "from their wings," specifying the means by which these luminous birds might spread light. This is an elaboration that adds a visual detail and a plausible mechanism not present in the original French, enhancing the imagery for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.
chunks.manualHtml: P061: I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the Vortex of Saturn? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.

explanations: The translator added 'at all' to 'I am not contented', intensifying the Marquise's dissatisfaction and making her statement more emphatic and natural in English.

The translator added 'in Mars' to the phrase ''tis a sign that there should be Moons,' specifying the location where the Marquise believes moons are needed. This directly links her general observation to the specific case of Mars, which is the focus of her subsequent (added) question.

The translator replaced the Marquise's declarative statement of disappointment about Mars with an added rhetorical question ('why should Mars only be excepted?'). This change makes her point more argumentative and direct, enhancing the conversational tone for the English audience.

The translator added the clause 'if ever you intend to make an end' to the advice about leaving some things aside. This addition provides a pragmatic justification for ignoring inconsistencies in philosophical systems, framing it as a necessary step to achieve closure.

The translator added 'if you please' to the philosopher's suggestion 'We will do so by Mars'. This acts as a polite conversational softener, making the suggestion more courteous and aligning with English dialogic conventions.

The translator added the phrase 'but return to Saturn.' after 'and say no more of him.' This addition explicitly guides the conversation back to the previous topic (Saturn), providing a clearer narrative transition for the reader which is not present in the source.

The translator transformed the philosopher's descriptive conditional statement about Saturn's ring by initiating the sentence with the added question 'What do you think of his great Ring,'. This textual addition makes the dialogue more interactive by directly prompting the Marquise, changing the declarative form of the source.

The translator added the specific noun 'Colonies' to the phrase 'I could almost send ... every where'. The source text ('à en envoyer par tout') implies sending people or inhabitants generally. This elaboration specifies the act as 'sending Colonies,' potentially invoking contemporary (17th/18th century) notions of settlement and expansion.

The translator added the clause 'they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet,' before the statement about Saturn's inhabitants expiring with heat. This introduces an anecdotal framing ('they say') and uses the vivid, culturally specific term 'Bagnio' (a very hot bath-house) to hyperbolically describe Greenland's relative temperature for Saturn's inhabitants. This makes the contrast more striking and culturally resonant for an English audience, as the source simply states the physical reaction (sweating and expiring) without this comparative and anecdotal layer.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.

P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
chunks.manualHtml: P062: You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew.

It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. explanations: The translator added "and are so very grave" to explicitly state the Saturnians' serious demeanor. The source text implies this gravity through their described behaviors (not laughing, slow responses) and their judgment of Cato. The target text makes this trait an explicit statement which then serves as the reason for their judgment of Cato ('that were Cato...'), enhancing clarity and emphasizing their character.

The translator replaced "trop badin & trop folâtre.." (too playful and too frolicsome) with "a merry Andrew." This term, referring to a buffoon or jester, introduces a specific English cultural reference and intensifies the judgment of Cato. While the source uses adjectives describing perceived excessive lightheartedness, the target uses a noun phrase that categorizes Cato as a particular type of foolish entertainer, thus adding a layer of meaning, cultural specificity, and stronger condemnation for the English audience.

chunks.sourceHtml: P082: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.
chunks.manualHtml: P063: It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.

Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.
explanations: The translator added 'It is odd to consider' to reframe the Marquise's simple statement 'A thought comes to me' ('Il me vient une pensée') as a more reflective or formal observation, possibly to enhance the character's contemplative tone for the English audience.

The translator added 'I suppose' to the Marquise's hypothesis. The French 'cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que...' is a speculative rhetorical question ('might it not be that...'). The addition of 'I suppose' makes the speculation more explicit and personalizes it as the Marquise's direct conjecture.

The translator added the interjection 'Why,' at the beginning of the philosopher's speech. This signals a shift in his response, from a direct agreement in the source ('J'aime assez cette idée') to a more nuanced interaction involving a question to the Marquise.

The translator inserted the question 'do you not approve of the Idea?' posed by the philosopher to the Marquise. This is a significant addition as the source text has the philosopher directly stating 'J'aime assez cette idée' ('I quite like this idea'), thus changing the conversational dynamic to be more inquisitive on the philosopher's part.

The translator added the clause 'we need not travel' as an explicit elaboration of the consequence of Earth's convenient position described in the source. While the source states it's 'commode d'être icy' (convenient to be here) to see worlds in epitome, it doesn't explicitly state this negates the need for travel.

The translator added 'at home' to specify 'icy' (here). This provides a more colloquial and culturally resonant expression for English readers, enhancing the sense of convenience and familiarity implied by the source.

chunks.sourceHtml: P083: Du moins, reprit la Marquise, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nôtre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce à la Nature d'être Homme, & non pas Bête, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moi je veux luy rendre grâce d'être sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grâce d'être jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vôtre Tourbillon, ou de la température de vôtre Pays.
chunks.manualHtml: P064: I am sure, says the Countess, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.

I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.
explanations: The source text begins with 'Du moins' (At least), which introduces the Countess's point with a degree of reservation or as a minimum claim. The target text's 'I am sure' adds a stronger assertion of personal conviction or certainty that is not explicitly present in the French, possibly to make the Countess's statement more emphatic for the English reader.

The source text 'un endroit de la Terre' (a place on Earth) is a general description. The target text 'our Country' adds a layer of specificity and localization, likely implying England to the contemporary English audience, thereby providing a more concrete and relatable context than the original French.

The source text uses a conditional or illustrative framing: 'si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce' (if a certain philosopher gave thanks). The target text's 'I have heard of a Philosopher' changes this to an assertion of received knowledge or an anecdote known to the speaker, adding a more personal and concrete dimension to the reference.

The source text 'Si vous m'en croyez... vous luy rendrez grâce' (If you believe me... you will/should give thanks) offers advice or a suggestion. The target 'You have more reason... to give thanks' introduces an explicit comparative judgment, asserting that the philosopher's subsequent reasons for gratitude are superior to the Countess's initial ones. This evaluative element ('more reason') is an addition by the translator.

The source text identifies the desirable nationality as 'Françoise' (French woman). The translator has changed this to 'an English Woman'. This is an instance of cultural adaptation, adding the specific context of 'English' to make the text more relevant or relatable to an English-speaking audience by substituting the original nationality with their own.

The source text contrasts the 'Françoise' (French woman) only with an 'Italienne' (Italian woman). The target text, after changing 'Françoise' to 'an English Woman', expands the list of less desirable nationalities by adding 'a Spaniard'. This nationality is entirely new content introduced by the translator, not present in the original source.

chunks.sourceHtml: P084: Mon Dieu! répliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a été donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considérables, un goût qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, répliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P065: Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.

If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.
explanations: The translator added "Sir" (as part of "Pray Sir," which translates the exclamation "Mon Dieu!"). This addition specifies the philosopher as the addressee of the Marquise's speech, a detail implied in the French dialogue but not explicitly stated in her initial exclamation. This makes the address more direct and aligns with English conversational norms of the period.

The translator added "at last" to the clause "and be sure to pay too dear for it at last," which corresponds to the French "on les payeroit bien" (one would pay dearly for them). This addition emphasizes the ultimate, eventual negative outcome of pursuing only intense pleasures, lending a stronger concluding emphasis to the Marquise's point.

The original French text has the philosopher asking the Marquise for a promise related to remembering him and the "Tourbillons" if offered "vivid pleasures." The translator significantly alters this by having the philosopher begin with "I wish... that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose." This introductory wish and the specific idea that "Philosophy was the pleasure you propose" are not present in the source's question, thus adding a new framing and content to the philosopher's speech.

The French source has the philosopher asking to be remembered simply as "moy" (me). The translator elaborates this significantly into the formal and courtly phrase "an humble Servant of your Ladyships." This addition introduces a level of politeness and social deference common in English literary style of the era, content not present in the more direct French original.

In the French text, the Marquise agrees ("Ouy") and then requests that philosophy continue to provide new pleasures ("mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux"). The English translation alters her response by adding the qualifying clause: "while it diverts innocently, but no longer." This condition, which frames her acceptance of philosophy as a pleasure only if it remains innocent and does not go too far, is entirely new material introduced by the translator, adding a moral or prudential dimension absent in the source.

The translator prepended the conjunction "for" to the philosopher's statement about the fixed stars. This addition creates a more explicit causal or explanatory link to his preceding assurance ("I will engage for it till to morrow"), suggesting the fixed stars are the basis for this continued pleasure. The French sentence is a more independent declaration.

chunks.sourceHtml: P085: CINQUIEME SOIR. Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde.
chunks.manualHtml: P066: The Fifth Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P066: The Fifth Evening.

chunks.sourceHtml: P086:. La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sauroient être moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuë, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumière, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuë; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.
chunks.manualHtml: P067: THE Countess was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of fifty millions of leagues; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.

explanations: The translator replaces the French phrase "& on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" (meaning "and one doesn't bother to count it") with the more evocative English phrase "it is almost beyond Arithmetick." This addition amplifies the concept of the immense distance with a more vivid, figurative expression not present in the understated French.

The source text states that reflection would significantly weaken the light ("une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup"). The translator adds the imperative phrase "then judge how much it is wasted by reflection;", directly engaging the reader and using the stronger term "wasted." This addition introduces a rhetorical element and an emphasis on light loss not explicitly formulated in this manner in the source.

While the source states the light would be sent back "à cette même distance" (at this same distance), the translator adds the explanatory clause "for it comes back again as far to us;". The conjunction "for" explicitly introduces a reason, and "comes back again as far" offers a more dynamic description of the return journey, clarifying the mechanism of light attenuation.

The source text mentions the light having "fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë" (travelled/made twice fifty million leagues). The translator expands this by adding "so that forwards and backwards," to explicitly clarify the nature of the doubled journey, and then explicitly calculates and states, "here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass;". This provides a more detailed explanation and calculation, enhancing clarity.

After the source text argues it's impossible for reflected light to be so strong, the translator adds the clause "which cannot but proceed from it self" to describe the light of a fixed star. This addition provides an explicit reason for the star's light being strong (i.e., it is self-generated), a crucial step in the argument that is not articulated in this way in the source.

chunks.sourceHtml: P087: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nôtre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Notre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..
chunks.manualHtml: P068: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
chunks.aiHtml: P068: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The translator replaced the French pronoun 'elle' (it), which refers to 'chaque Etoile Fixe' (each Fixed Star) within the source phrase 'autour d'elle' (around it), with the explicit noun phrase 'the fix'd Star'. This addition is part of the target phrase 'that turns round the fix'd Star?' and serves to clarify the referent, enhancing comprehension in English by making the object of 'turns round' explicit.

The translator replaced the French anaphoric pronoun 'en' (them/some of them), which refers to 'Planetes' (Planets) implied from the preceding clause, with the explicit noun 'Planets' in the target phrase 'have Planets'. This addition clarifies what each fixed star might possess, reinforcing the idea for the English reader and maintaining parallelism.

The translator added 'and I will not contradict you' to make the philosopher's agreement explicit. The source text's concluding phrase 'C'est toi qui l'as nommé..' (a literary allusion meaning 'It is you who named him/it') implies this agreement. The addition ensures the philosopher's confirmatory stance is clearly and directly communicated to an English audience potentially unfamiliar with the allusion, thereby supplementing the translation 'You have said it'.

chunks.sourceHtml: P088: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-être aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes & Tout cet espace immense qui comprend notre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moi, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le ciel n'étoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles êtoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte, en la partageant en mille & mille Tourbillons, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & assurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous côtés les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..
chunks.manualHtml: P069: You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably more magnificent than it was before. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.

Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? I protest it is dreadful. explanations: The source text has 'je ne suis plus rien' (I am nothing anymore), expressing a sense of existential diminishment. The translator replaces/elaborates this with 'or what will become of me,' adding a future-oriented anxiety that provides a different nuance to the Marquise's distress.

The source text, 'Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante,' describes the Marquise's internal feelings. The translator adds the phrase 'I protest' before the rendition of these feelings ('it is dreadful'), turning her internal state into an explicit verbal declaration not present in the original French.

The translator adds the vocative 'Madam' when the philosopher responds to the Marquise. This is a common addition in English translations of this period to convey politeness and reflect social conventions in dialogue, thereby normalizing the text for the target audience.

The source text states 'je m'y sentois comme oppressé' (I felt as if oppressed/stifled there). The translator adds 'for want of Air,' providing a specific cause or explanation for the feeling of being stifled, making the sensation more concrete and vivid for the reader.

The source 'toute une autre magnificence' (a whole other magnificence / quite a different magnificence) implies a comparison to its previous state. The translator makes this notion more emphatic and explicit by adding the intensifier 'incomparably' and the comparative clause 'than it was before,' thus elaborating on the contrast.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P089: Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de notre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; aprés eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les aperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous êtes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis & Nous mêmes, à qui la même expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. Assurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoît pas les Tourbillons.. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondrai: Ah! si vous saviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'êtoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fût dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?). mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eût êté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eût pas pu conquerir. A plus forte raison lui eût-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eût connus en ce temps-là; c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.

P090: C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle, en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez- moi franchement, votre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-même comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De même accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-même il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroît, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroît point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune êtoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nôtre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous êtes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nôtre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.
chunks.manualHtml: P070: You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet I must confess I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.

explanations: The translator added 'in part' to qualify the extent to which the 'new lights' (nouvelles lumieres) would justify the Marquise's laziness. This addition subtly moderates the claim, making it sound more natural or less absolute in English.

The source 'Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su' translates more directly to 'Alexander must not have known it' or 'It is necessary that he did not know.' The translator's 'It was not fit' introduces a judgment or a sense of propriety/appropriateness that is not explicitly in the source, subtly shifting the reason why Alexander shouldn't have known.

The source's parenthetical question '(comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?)' (how could a truth have escaped Aristotle?) is rephrased by the translator into a descriptive clause '(from whom no truth could be long conceal'd)'. The word 'long' is added within this rephrasing, implying a duration of concealment that is not explicitly in the source, thus slightly elaborating on the idea that truth wouldn't escape Aristotle for any significant period.

The source 'qui eût êté au despoir' means 'who would have been in despair.' The translator intensifies this to 'run mad with despair,' adding a layer of psychological extremity ('run mad with') not explicitly present in the original phrase, likely for dramatic effect.

The source 'c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler.' means 'it would have been to pay one's court very badly' or 'it would have been very unpolitic.' The translator renders this as 'a Man would have been a great Fool,' which adds a direct judgment about the person's intelligence ('a great Fool') rather than describing the imprudence of the action itself. This makes the statement more blunt for the target audience.

The translator first renders the sense of 'c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour' with 'a Man would have been a great Fool.' Then, they add the clause 'it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince;' This clause serves as an explicit explanation or restatement of the French idiom 'faire mal sa Cour' (to pay court badly/to curry favor ineptly), clarifying its meaning for the English audience. The addition of 'to that ambitious Prince' also provides context for why it would be an ill way to make court.

The source word 'l'inquietude' means anxiety, restlessness, or disquiet. The translator elaborates this single noun into the phrase 'their unquiet restless humour.' The addition of 'humour' (in the older sense of disposition or temperament) and the somewhat redundant but emphatic 'unquiet restless' serves to expand on the concept, making it more vivid for the English reader.

The source 'Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal,' translates to 'A little weakness for what is beautiful, that's my ailment.' The translator expands the first part by adding the introductory phrase 'I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as'. This addition ('I confess, I am guilty of... as') frames the admission more formally and emphatically than the simpler 'Un peu de foiblesse' in the source, and also changes 'a little' (un peu) to 'so much'.

chunks.sourceHtml: P091: Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nôtre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nôtre, qui n'y paroît que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est-à-dire des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, notre Terre, par exemple, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont uniques en leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?
chunks.manualHtml: P071: This Love, reply'd the Countess, smiling, is a strange thing; let the World go how 'twill, 'tis never in danger; there is no System can do it any harm. But tell me freely, is your System true? Pray conceal nothing from me; I will keep your secret very faithfully; it seems to have for its foundation, but a slight probability; which is, that if a fix'd Star be in it self a luminous Body, like the Sun, then by consequence, it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World; and have its Planets turning round about it: But is there an absolute necessity it must be so? Madam, said I, since we are in the humour of mingling amorous Follies with our most serious Discourses, I must tell you, that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike: Allow never so little to a Lover, yet presently after you must grant him more; nay more and more, which will at last go a great way: In like manner, grant but a Mathematician one little Principle, he immediately draws a consequence from it, to which you must necessarily assent; and from this consequence another, till he leads you so far (whether you will or no) that you have much ado to believe him. These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians, will always take more than you give 'em. You grant that when two things are like one another in all those things that appear to you, it is possible they may be like one another in those things that are not visible, if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise: Now this way of arguing have I made use of. The Moon, say I, is inhabited, because she is like the Earth; and the other Planets are inhabited, because they are like the Moon; I find the fix'd Stars to be like our Sun, therefore I attribute to them what is proper to that: You are now gone too far to be able to retreat, therefore you must go forward with a good grace. But, says the Countess, if you build upon this resemblance or likeness which is between our Sun and the fix'd Stars, then, to the People of another great Vortex, our Sun must appear no bigger than a small fix'd Star, and can be seen only when 'tis Night with them. Without doubt, Madam, said I, it must be so: Our Sun is much nearer to us, than the Suns of other Vortex's, and therefore its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do: We see nothing but the light of our own Sun, and when we see that, it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light: but in another great Vortex, there is another Sun, which rules and governs, and, in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun, which is never seen there, but in the Night, with the rest of the other Suns, that is the fix'd Stars; with them our Sun is fastned to the great arched roof of Heaven, where it makes a part of some Bear or Bull: For the Planets which turn round about it, (our Earth for Example) as they are not seen at so vast a distance, so no body doth so much as dream of 'em: All the Suns then are Day Suns in their own Vortex's, but Night Suns in other Vortex's: In his own World or Sphere every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen; but every where else, they serve only to make a number. May not the Worlds, reply'd the Countess, notwithstanding this great resemblance between 'em, differ in a thousand other things; for tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.

explanations: This entire extensive dialogue section is added at the beginning of the target text paragraph P071, preceding the translation of the first sentence of the provided source text P091 ('Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je.'). It introduces a lengthy exchange—covering topics like love, the system's truth, reasoning in love versus mathematics, analogical arguments for extraterrestrial life, and the Countess's initial question about the Sun's appearance from other vortices—none of which is present in the supplied source segment. This addition significantly expands the conversational context and narrative before the philosopher's affirmation that corresponds to the start of the French source.

The translator added 'Madam,' a vocative addressing the Countess, into the philosopher's reply. The French 'répondis-je' (I replied) does not contain this direct address. This addition serves to make the dialogue more explicit and adheres to English conversational conventions of the period, adding politeness.

The phrase ', it must be so' is an addition that follows 'Without doubt'. The French 'Cela est hors de doute' (That is beyond doubt) is already conveyed by 'Without doubt.' The addition of 'it must be so' serves to emphatically confirm the statement, possibly for rhetorical weight or to create a more natural English cadence.

The French 'il efface tout' (it erases everything) is expanded into the more descriptive phrase 'it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light.' This addition clarifies the mechanism by which the Sun's brightness 'erases' other celestial objects from view, making the scientific point more explicit for the reader.

The French 'qui y domine' (which dominates there/in it) is translated using the doublet 'which rules and governs.' This expansion uses two near-synonymous verbs, a common rhetorical practice in older English translations, to add emphasis or fullness to the expression of dominance.

The French 'il efface à son tour le nôtre' (it in turn erases ours [our Sun]) is rendered as 'in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun.' The addition of 'the light of' specifies that it is the visibility or light of our Sun that is 'extinguished,' rather than the Sun itself, providing a more precise astronomical explanation.

The translator adds 'or Sphere' after 'World' when translating 'Dans leur Monde' (In their World). This addition provides an alternative or clarifying term for 'Monde,' possibly to encompass the astronomical concept of a celestial sphere or domain associated with each sun, or to offer a slightly more technical synonym for the target audience.

The French 'ils sont uniques en leur espece' (they are unique in their kind) is translated and elaborated as 'every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen.' The clause 'and there is but one to be seen' is an addition that makes explicit the consequence of being 'unique' or 'single' in its own vortex—that it is the only sun visible there.

The French phrase 'un fond de ressemblance' (a basis/foundation of resemblance) is rendered in the context of the question as 'tho' they may be alike in one particular.' The addition 'in one particular' specifies and narrows the nature of the 'fond de ressemblance,' making the Countess's philosophical point about similarities versus infinite differences more sharply defined for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P092: Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que say-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour de Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extrémitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vide. Je ne doute pas même qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'êtant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.
chunks.manualHtml: P072: It is certainly true, said I; but the difficulty is to know wherein they differ. One Vortex hath many Planets that turn round about its Sun; another Vortex hath but a few: In one Vortex, there are inferiour or less Planets, which turn about those that are greater; in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets; here, all the Planets are got round about their Sun, in form of a little Squadron; beyond which, is a great void space, which reacheth to the neighbouring Vortex's: In another place, the Planets take their course towards the out side of their Vortex, and leave the middle void. There may be Vortex's also quite void, without any Planets at all; others may have their Sun not exactly in their Centre; and that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it: others may have Planets which in regard of their Sun, ascend and descend, according to the change of their Equilibration, which keeps them suspended. But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.

But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.
explanations: The French 'de deviner' means 'to guess' or 'to figure out.' The translator added 'to know wherein they differ' to make explicit what needs to be guessed, specifying that the philosopher is trying to determine the ways in which the vortices vary. This provides greater clarity for the reader.

The French 'Planetes subalternes' means 'subordinate planets.' The translator used 'inferiour Planets' and added 'or less' to provide a more common or understandable equivalent for 'inferiour' (which translates 'subalternes'), likely referring to size or significance, thus ensuring clarity for the English audience.

The French 'il n'y en a point' ('there are none at all') is an assertive statement. The translator added 'perhaps' to introduce a degree of speculation or uncertainty that is not present in the original French text, softening the assertion.

The French 'en' is a pronoun referring back to 'Planetes subalternes.' The translator chose to explicitly restate 'inferiour Planets' instead of using a pronoun like 'them' or 'any.' This addition serves to make the reference clearer and more direct for the reader, avoiding potential ambiguity.

The French 'font comme un petit peloton' means 'they are like a small group' or 'they form something like a small group.' The translator uses 'in form of a little Squadron,' where 'in form of a' explicitly specifies that the likeness pertains to the shape or arrangement, an aspect that is more implicit in the simpler French 'comme' (like/as).

The French 'sans Planetes' simply means 'without planets.' The translator added 'at all' after 'without any Planets' to intensify the statement, emphasizing the complete absence of planets for greater rhetorical effect.

The French phrase 'ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy' means '(the Sun) has a real movement, and carries its Planets with it.' The translator rendered the latter part as 'that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it.' The phrase 'may so move, as to' adds modality ('may') and a description of manner or consequence ('so move, as to') not explicitly present in the more direct French conjunction, thereby elaborating on how the sun's movement results in carrying the planets.

The French text has 'Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez...' ('Finally, what more would you want? There's quite enough...'). The translator omits the rhetorical question 'Enfin, que voudriez-vous?' and prefaces the translation of 'En voila bien assez...' with 'But I think.' This addition ('But I think') introduces the speaker's explicit thought process and personal judgment into the discourse, framing the subsequent statement.

chunks.sourceHtml: P093: Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?
chunks.manualHtml: P073: It is not so much, reply'd the Countess, considering what a multitude of Worlds there are; what you have said is sufficient but for five or six, and from hence I see thousands.
chunks.aiHtml: P073: It is not so much, reply'd the Countess, considering what a multitude of Worlds there are; what you have said is sufficient but for five or six, and from hence I see thousands.
explanations: The translator specified the speaker by using 'the Countess' where the source text uses the pronoun 'elle' (she) within 'répondit-elle' (she replied). This addition provides immediate clarity as to who is speaking, potentially for an audience that might prefer explicit identification over pronominal reference.

The translator elaborated the concise French prepositional phrase 'pour la quantité des Mondes' (meaning 'given the quantity of worlds' or 'in view of the quantity of worlds') into the more descriptive English clause 'considering what a multitude of Worlds there are'. This expansion makes the reasoning more explicit and rhetorically stronger, notably through the use of the emphatic 'what a', the explicit verb 'there are', and the choice of 'multitude' over a more neutral term for 'quantité'.

chunks.sourceHtml: P094: Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-être douze ou quinze, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyait auparavant dans le Ciel?
chunks.manualHtml: P074: What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you, there are many more fix'd Stars than those you see? and that an infinite number are discover'd with Glasses, which never shew'd themselves to our Eyes: In only one Constellation, where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen, there are as many to be found as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere.
chunks.aiHtml: P074: What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you, there are many more fix'd Stars than those you see? and that an infinite number are discover'd with Glasses, which never shew'd themselves to our Eyes: In only one Constellation, where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen, there are as many to be found as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere.
explanations: The translator added 'Madam' as a direct term of address to the Marquise. While the French 'vous' implies formality, 'Madam' makes the address more explicit and aligns with English conventions of politeness in dialogue for the period, enhancing naturalness.

The translator added 'usually' to the phrase. The source 'auparavant' means 'previously' or 'before,' referring to a past observation. The addition of 'usually' shifts this to a habitual or general occurrence, potentially to frame the philosopher's statement as a more established scientific observation rather than a singular past perception.

The translator elaborated 'dans le Ciel' (in the Sky) to 'in the whole Hemisphere'. 'Hemisphere' is a more scientifically precise term for 'Ciel' in an astronomical context, providing clarity. The word 'whole' was added to 'Hemisphere' to emphasize the completeness of this celestial area, making the subsequent comparison more impactful.

chunks.sourceHtml: P095: Je vous demande grâce, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je say bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmiliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux îles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites îles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voie de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou même se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oiseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroît tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous êtes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voie de Lait, votre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc votre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lorsque vous perdez de veuë votre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & votre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas être sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres trs-profondes, & qui, quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent même qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Etres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de notre condition.
chunks.manualHtml: P075: I submit, says the Countess, and beg your pardon: You quite confound me with Worlds and Vortex's. I have yet more to tell you, Madam, said I: You see that whiteness in the Sky, which some call the milky way; Can you imagine what that is? 'Tis nothing but an infinity of small Stars, not to be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very little; and they are sown so thick, one by another, that they seem to be one cotinu'd whiteness: I wish you had a Glass, to see this Ant-hill of Stars, and this Cluster of Worlds, if I may so call 'em: They are in some sort, like the Maldivian Islands: those twelve thousand banks of Sand, separated by narrow Channels of the Sea, which a Man may leap as easily, as over a Ditch: So near together are the Vortex's of the Milky way, that the People in one World, may talk, and shake Hands with those of another; at least I believe, the Birds of one World, may easily fly into another; and that Pigeons may be train'd up to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. These little Worlds are excepted out of that general Rule, by which one Sun in his own Vortex, as soon as he appears, effaceth the light of all other forreign Suns: If you were in one of these little Vortex's of the Milky way, your Sun would not be much nearer to you, and consequently, would not make any much greater sensible impression on your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Vortex's: You would then see your Heaven shine bright with an infinite number of Fires, close to one another, and but a little distant from you; so that tho' you should lose the light of your own particular Sun, yet there would still remain visible Suns enough beside your own, to make your Night as light as Day, at least, the difference would hardly be perceiv'd, for the truth is, you would never have any Night at all: The Inhabitants of these Worlds accustom'd to perpetual Brightness, would be strangely astonish'd, if they should be told that there are a miserable sort of People, who where they live, have very dark Nights, and when 'tis Day with them, they never see more than one Sun; certainly they would think Nature had very little kindness for us, and would tremble with horrour, to think what a sad condition we are in.
